description.narrative: independent political entity
Elections - elections

provider-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Republic of korea

description.narrative: 1. Extent to which Credible, Transparent and Sustainable Electoral Processes has been established. 2. Extent to which there is an Improvement in the Democratic Quality of Political Engagement. 3. Extent to which there is an enhancement of the participation by Women, Youth and other marginalized groups 4. Extent to which Channels of Civic Engagement has been strengthened.

comment.narrative: 1. Partially - Credible, Transparent and Sustainable Electoral Process yet to be mainstreamed. 2. Partially - Quality of Political Engagement needs to meet the standard set in the 2012-2016 Strategic Programme of Action. 3. Partially - The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) Gender Policy is yet to be developed 4. Partially - Relatively low levels of civic awareness of and engagement with government and elections at local and State levels.

1. Increased communication and cooperation between INEC, political parties, CSOs and key stakeholders to improve public approval of electoral operations and contribute to peaceful elections. 2. Electoral procedures, and voter education materials are appropriate to women, youths and PWDs 3. Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) are proactively and constructively engaged in informing and monitoring the electoral process in the lead up to the 2015 elections. 4. Monitor and report the experiences of women during elections to address violence and ensure peaceful elections where women participate freely

1. The Abuja Accord on peaceful election was signed by key political parties and presidential candidates. 2. Nigeria held its widely acclaimed, free, credible and peaceful elections. 3. The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) instituted the National Interagency Committee on Voter Education and Publicity (NICVEP) which ensured that electoral procedures, and voter education materials were appropriate to women, youths and other marginalized groups. 4. A Women Situation room was established in collaboration with UNWOMEN at the national and 10 state levels which monitored the election and reported incidents of violence against women. The commitments secured from the political parties, youth and the media contributed to the reduced violence incidents while the rapid response mechanism in place addressed issues of violence.

title.narrative: EU ADDL SUPPT TO ELECTORAL CYC

description.narrative: EU ADDITIONAL SUPPORT TO NIGERIA ELECTORAL CYCLE 2011 - 2015
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

1. Extent to which the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) performance benchmarks achieved within set timelines. 2. Independent National Electoral Commission’s level of information sharing with stakeholder.

comment.narrative: 1. Partially - the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) launched its Strategic Programme of Action 2012-2016 with performance benchmarks in June 2013 2. Partially - During the previous electoral cycles, there were no deliberate efforts to share the observation reports beyond the press conference and the lodgment of the reports with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC).

1. Conduct extensive voter education campaigns with a focus on youth, women and peaceful elections covering all the states of the Federation 2. Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) to set up and run an Election Management System for effective and efficient operation and coordination of crucial aspects of election administration and management for the 2015 general elections. 3. Build capacity of the Election Petition Tribunals developed with a view to fast- track adjudication of election petitions and address issues of inconsistent judgements.

1. Achieved: Comprehensive voter education campaigns were delivered in all the 774 Local Government Areas of the Federation through both traditional and nontraditional mechanisms which contributed to increased voter turnout and reduced invalid votes. 2. Partially Achieved: INEC significantly improved on the 2015 electoral process with the automation of many electoral processes, including the deployment and retrieval of electoral materials and personnel and the development of manuals for the efficient operationalization of the appropriate channels of communication and electoral support infrastructure. 3. Achieved: The Election Petition Tribunals had managed to fast- track the election adjudication process with no reported case of election petition lapses and inconsistent judgements

description.narrative: Mainstream biodiversity development priorities into OG Sector policies and operations using the governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity and also the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a development mechanism for local communities.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

The objective of the project is aimed towards mainstreaming of biodiversity management priorities into the oil and gas sector development policies and operations especially in the Niger Delta communities
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Extent to which governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the OG sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened. 2. Extent to which Government, the OG industry and local communities build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta. 3. Extent to which stakeholders support long-term biodiversity management in the Niger Delta by capitalizing and accessing the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, OG companies and Government.

comment.narrative: 1. Not adequate – there is weak governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the OG sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened. 2. Not adequate - Government, the OG industry and local communities are yet to build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta. 3. Not adequate - A Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, OG companies and Government does not exist.

1. Review of Policy document on the Oil and Gas industry. 2. Status of the barrier islands surveyed and documented. 3. Short courses mainstreamed into curriculum of training institutions in the Niger Delta.
1. Barrier islands surveyed and endangered species documented and mapped out. 2. Short courses developed but yet to be mainstreamed into the curriculum of training institutes in the Niger Delta
- Complete the community BAPs - Reports for gazetted areas - Oil and Gas Reports

 Carried out CBAP IN 15 Communities in various Local Government Areas of the Niger Delta States  Carried development of IBAT Tool  Mainstream of Niger Delta Biodiversity studies into Secondary School curriculum  Published the oil and Gas Plan report  Published the Sacred Groove Report  Developed a project identification framework  Developed report for gazetted areas
Complete the mid-term evaluation for the project

description.narrative: To mainstream biodiversity management priorities into the Niger Delta oil and gas OG sector development policies and operations
Direct Improved management of 600 km2 inside the fence of OG operations as measured by adoption of Biodiversity Action Plans for a target number of OG operations in the Delta

comment.narrative:
SPDC has carried out BAPs in the following states
Akwa Ibom 1
Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve SPDC has no footprints in this tract but it still carried out the BAP the OG company working in the area ExxonMobil has not cooperated with SPDC or this project to consider further investments in the Forest Reserve The situation has further been complicated by new Oil Mineral Licenses OML leases in the area
Bayelsa state
BAP development in Bayelsa has focussed on the GbaranUbie integrated oil and gas project The following Forest Reserves have been the subject of BAP in bayelsa a Apoi Creek Forest Reserve b Nun River Forest Reserve c Taylor Creek Forest Reserve⃰ straddling Bayelsa and Rivers states d Edumanom e Egbedi and f Ikebiri Forest Reserves SPDC has not signed off on these recently conducted BAPs
Rivers state 2
Upper Orashi Forest Reserve
Taylor Creek Forest Reserve straddliding⃰
⃰
At least 600 km2 of OG footprint covered by new or revised BAP for OG operations in ND
A combined figure of 80608 hectares has been subject of BAP in three statesAkwa Ibom Bayelsa and Rivers state

description.narrative: Government the OG industry and local communities build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta
Change in level of corporate investment in biodiversity management

comment.narrative: TBD at project inception
A 20 increase in corporate investment of OG companies in biodiversity management will ensure biodiversity safeguarding at OG extraction sites pipeline and tanker transportation

SPDC is maintaining some level of investments in its corporate biodiversity portfolio But this has dwindled in the last three years Serious consideation is still given to biodiversity in all development projects Fall in global oil pices and divestment policies have been implicated in scaling down of biodiversity related activities

description.narrative: of OG companies adopting new BAP for operations

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 3 companies adopt model BAP for their inside the fence operations
SPDC has adopted BAP as an integral part of its environment policy

description.narrative: The project will help to reflect national context and priorities ,national policies and country-driven of the Hydro-chlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) Management plan.
independent political entity

1. Extent of Hydrochlorofluorocarbons usage in the foam and refrigeration sectors 2. Extent to which System House at Vitapur has been upgraded for Supply of Methyl Formate-Based Systems to the Nigerian Foam Industry

comment.narrative: 1. Limited Hydrochlorofluorocarbons usage in the foam and refrigeration sectors 2. Not adequate - System House at Vitapur has not been upgraded for Supply of Methyl Formate-Based Systems to the Nigerian Foam Industry

1. Completion of the conversion process of the Methyl Formate plant in Lagos State 2. Retrofit two high pressure dispensers in the System House at Vitapur 3. Conduct a Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFC) technology demonstration and training seminar.

1. Achieved - Hydrochloroflourocarbon (HCFC) Plant in Lagos State commissioned. 2. Achieved - Methyl Formate conversion processes completed in Viatpur Partially achieved - Training postponed till 2016
- Commence Stage II preparation - HCFC Consumption audits

- Carried out an upgrade of data hub for the Ozone Office - Carried out a study on the use of Pu System in the North West region of Nigeria - Carried HCFC Consumption Audit in Nigeria - Held a major key stake holders meeting with NAFDAC focusing on the regulatory requirement of HCFC related substances and goods.
Commence HPMP Stage II implementation

description.narrative: 1. Extent to which the project’s institutional and technical capacity strengthened in Cross River State (CRS). 2. Level of stakeholder’s support to and engagement in the project. 3. Extent to which a Centre of excellence on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) has been established in Cross River State (CRS). 4. Development of national strategies or action plans

comment.narrative: 1. Not adequate - there is limited institutional and technical capacity strengthened in Cross River State for the project implementation. 2. Not adequate - stakeholder’s awareness and support is low. 3. Not adequate - Cross River State (CRS) is currently not a Centre of excellence on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+ 4. Non-existence of Road map for Nigeria REDD+ Framework and Strategy.

1. Established a Centre of excellence learning on REDD+ in Cross River State 2. Design of a financing mechanism on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) 3. Preparation of investment plans and enabling programme for REDD+ 4. Creation and administration of a fund to support community initiatives for REDD+

- Centre of excellence learning on REDD+ in Cross River State established - Consultants recruited on financing mechanism on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) -Consultants recruited to work on financing options at state level
Finalize on the Nigeria REDD+ Strategy

The project focused majorly on producing the Cross River State Policy on REDD and the National Policy on REDD with input from the national and international consultants by carrying series of studies in the different sectors and by holding stakeholders and validation workshops to ensure the two policies are produced.

description.narrative: 1. Number of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) trained by the project in networking, partnership- building, project planning, implementation and reporting in relation to anti-corruption interventions. 2. Number of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) benefitting from CSO Anti-Corruption Grant scheme.

comment.narrative: 1. 0 – Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) have limited capacity to articulate and aggregate their interest and engage in advocacy on Government’s anti-corruption interventions 2. 0 – No Civil Society Organization (CSO) is currently benefitting from CSO Anti-Corruption Grant scheme.

1. Organize/support two CSO Advisory Committee Meetings 2. Customized project management and thematic anti-corruption trainings for CSOs 3. Provide capacity-building and work towards enabling the grants scheme design an award grant scheme. 4. Support meetings of 3 anti-corruption networks 5. Production of anti-corruption Outreach materials

1. Largely achieved- Two meetings of CSO Advisory Committee provided strategic guidance and approved the Workplans for the implementation of the Project. 2. Largely Achieved- CSOs partnership-building Workshops enhanced CSO access to ACAs 3. Largely Achieved- CSOs capacitated to offer top-notch application for, and implementation of Project and Grants. 4. Largely Achieved- CSO Networks articulated and aggregated their Agenda within a coordinated framework with the Presidential Advisory Committee on Anti-Corruption. 5. Largely Achieved- Dissemination of Documentary on Corruption enhanced awareness among CSOs.

(a). DRR Platform workshop was carried out (b). DRR Training (c). Developed a DRR Information System (d). A Formulation of DRM was carried out by the agency (e). Gender Assessment carried out
Strengthen agency strategies, plans and operations for effective disaster risk reduction, recovery and resilient building.

description.narrative: The project aims to promote culture of peace, integrate anti-corruption measures into public sector management and improve human rights monitoring, investigations, reporting and redressing mechanisms including HIV/AIDS.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of proposals for legal reform to fight discrimination (e.g. against people affected by HIV, PWD, women, minorities and migrants) that have been adopted

Organize technical training on conflict prevention, commemorate 2015 International Day of Peace; train security personnel, NEMA, SEMAs, Red Cross, CSOs, etc in the north east on protection of civilians and camp management;
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Extent to which a holistic framework for addressing conflict issues is in place; 2. Extent to which a collaboration mechanism for security agencies is in place for coordinated response to violent conflict. 3. Availability of a socio-economic impact assessment report on the north east. 4. Extent to which the Niger Delta socio-economic data bank is up to date.

comment.narrative: 1. Absence of a holistic framework for addressing conflict issues; 2. Absence of effective collaboration mechanism among security agencies in maintain peace in violent conflict 3. No Socio-economic impact assessment report on the north east 4. Socio-economic data bank on Niger Delta was established in 2012 and needed to be populated

1. Largely Achieved- Women adopted follow-up activities to engender peace in the North-East 2. Not Achieved- Change in country context necessitated re-programing for Debris and Waste Management Assessment 3. Largely Assessment- Baseline Assessment provide empirical gaps in socio-economic interventions in the Niger Delta 4. Achieved- Training of personnel enhanced beneficiaries’ knowledge on civilian protection and camp management 5. Achieved- commemorative activities enhance awareness of peacebuilding among stakeholders.

- Conduct and publish 2016 edition of Strategic Conflict Assessment and report. - Two communities with existence of peace building infrastructure. - Conduct refresher course for 200 Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps (NSCDC) Peace Officers on alternative dispute resolution (ADR) and share experience on best practice. - Train strategic level officers across all security agencies in Nigeria on intelligence sharing, effective co-ordination and crisis management. - Validate the report of socio-economic and infrastructure resource database in the Niger Delta. - Design and install monitoring and evaluation system to track Niger Delta development in the Ministry of Niger Delta Affairs (MNDA). - Place 495 victims of insurgency in the North East in technical and vocational skill centres for 6 months to one year programme.

- 2016 edition of Strategic Conflict Assessment draft report ready. - 15 communities in 5 states have functional community peace building infrastructure. - 230 NSCDC Peace Officers retrained on alternative dispute resolution (ADR) and shared experiences on best practice. A remarkable 12,134 civil cases resolved by the officers in 2016. - 351 strategic level security officers across all security agencies in Nigeria trained on intelligence sharing, effective co-ordination and crisis management. - The report of socio-economic and infrastructure resource database in the Niger Delta validated. - Web-based monitoring and evaluation system to track Niger Delta development designed, installed and functional in MNDA. - 258 of the 495 reoriented women and youths, victims of insurgency in the North East, placed in a technical and a vocational skill acquisition centre for 6 months (179) and one year (79) period respectively.

description.narrative: STRENGTHENED ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY IN FEDERAL AND SELECTED STATES
independent political entity
Anti corruption
Proportion States that have adopted relevant laws in compliance with international standards

comment.narrative: 24 States that have adopted relevant laws in compliance with international standards

1. Empower youth in Ebonyi State through dynamic and innovative platforms to promote integrity and public accountability. 2. Facilitate the adoption of Integrity Plan on Corruption Risk Assessments in three related Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) at national levels as part of measures to strengthen public accountability mechanisms. 3. Conduct corruption risk assessment in three airports 4. Launch of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and Anti-corruption (ACs) for the port agencies

1. Partially achieved- Youths in Ebonyi State disseminated key anti-corruption messages through radio programmes. 2. Achieved- Report of CRA in three MDAs strengthened the baseline information on public accountability mechanisms in the public sector. 3. Largely Achieved- Assessment Conducted in the Airport Sector. 4. Largely Achieved- SOPs and AC Policies are being harmonized.

1. Training of Trainers - 20 Corruption Risk Assessors – by Anti-Corruption Academy of Nigeria. 2. Support to the publication and dissemination of the Report of CRA in Aviation Sector 3. Support to the implementation of Port Sector CRA 4. Joint BPP/CSO Monitoring Exercises of Procurement Processes and Bids in the Ministries of Water, Health and Education 5. Publication and dissemination of Report of the Corruption Risk Assessment carried out in MDG related MDAs of Education, Health and Water Resources 6. Training of members of the anti-corruption and transparency monitoring units (ACTUs), SERVICOM, Procurement Units and Efficiency Units of MDAs on Integrated and Coordinated Procurement Processes and Monitoring Budget Implementation in their agencies to enhance integrity and public accountability. 7. Publication/printing of report of the scoping survey and gap analysis of PFM in Akwa-Ibom State 8. Capacity building South-South Cooperation with ECOWAS

1. Fully Achieved-42 CSOs/civil servants were trained and certified as corruption risk assessors. 100 LMS licenses acquired 2. Fully achieved-1000 copies of the report printed and presented to the public on 9 December 2016. 3. Largely achieved-two major recommendations of the CRA reports were implemented - Ports Support Service Portal Standard Operating Procedures of the Ports agencies were launched by the Vice President of Nigeria. 4. Achieved-incorporated into Activity 6. 5. Achieved-report printed. 6. Largely achieved-CSOs components was integrated. 7. Achieved-1000 copies of the report printed. 8. Fully achieved-Experience sharing mission was in Ghana during the Executive Committee meeting of the ECOWAS Civil Society Platform on Transparency Accountability in Governance (ECSOPTAG)

1. Achieved - Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) validated 2. Largely achieved - State level implementation of the National Plan of Action on Gender Based Violence (GBV)/HIV intersections conducted raising awareness and action plan developed in three States of Niger, Kogi Anambra 3. Achieved - HIV/AIDS Anti-stigma Discrimination Bill validated in three States of Niger, Kogi Anambra. 4. Achieved - Gender and Human Rights Technical Working Group established in Niger and Kogi States

1. Validation of Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) for HIV response in Nigeria 2. Development of National action Plan for removing Legal and Human Right barrier to HIV response in Nigeria with special focus on key and vulnerable populations. 3. Development of State of Human Right Report in Adamawa, Borno and Yobe

1. Achieved - Validation conducted for Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) for HIV response in Nigeria 2. Achieved - National action Plan for removing Legal and Human Right barrier to HIV response in Nigeria with special focus on key and vulnerable populations developed in partnership with key stakeholders. 3. Achieved - State of Human Right Report in Adamawa, Borno and Yobe developed

The 2015 Development Cooperation Report was completed at the National level and in one State 4. The Sub-national Aid Coordination Platform meeting was successfully convened.

Review and adopt aid coordination framework at sub-national levels. 3. Produce Needs Assessment Document (NAD) and design action plan. 4. Design SDGs data bond for federal and state officers 5. Re-design Statistical Year Book (SYB) using SDGs indicators in 6 states.

description.narrative: 1. Number of entrepreneurship boot camp training has been conducted. 2. Number of youths trained and empowered in key skill areas. 3. Number of physically challenged persons trained on vocational skills for self-employment

comment.narrative: 1. Zero entrepreneurship boot camp training has been conducted. 2. 130 youths so far trained and empowered in key skill areas. 3. 40 physically challenged persons trained on vocational skills for self-employment

1. Conduct a Vocational Skills empowerment training for 50 physically challenged persons in one State. 2. Conduct Vocational Training for 1000 Youths and Women in selected trades (carpentry, welding and fitting, tailoring, tye and dying, soap making, baking) 3. Design an Entrepreneurial Monitor for recording of entrepreneurial developments/characteristics of self employed trainees

1. 40 physically challenged persons benefitted from the vocational training programme and have all commenced self-businesses in shoe making, hairdressing and tailoring. 2. 600 youths and women benefitted in vocational training programmes conducted in Gombe, Kogi and Niger States 3. An Entrepreneurial Monitor has been successfully designed in Niger and Anambra States and pilot tested in Niger State

1. Conduct skills acquisition and livelihood empowerment training for youths, women and women cooperatives in some states. 2. Train and equip 40 physically challenged persons in four skill areas in one state 3. Design state Entrepreneurial monitor guide and platform for periodic monitoring of skills training beneficiaries. 4. Conduct mentorship attachment training for skills training youth benecificiaries.

1. Skills Acquisition and livelihood empowerment training for youths, women and women cooperatives completed in Gombe, Niger and Kogi states. 2. Forty (40) physically challenged persons trained and empowered with equipment. 3. Entrepreneurial monitor guide designed for periodic monitoring of beneficiaries in Kogi. 4. Mentorship attachment training successfully conducted for 200 youths in Delta.

1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

comment.narrative: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns in Nigeria's six geo-political zones was carried out. 3. Largely achieved - training took place in Akwa Ibom, Enugu and Sokoto. 4. Not achieved - Activity yet to be carried out. 5. Not achieved - needs assessment of community based micro projects yet to be done

description.narrative: Support to Early Recovery and Social Cohesion in the North East (SERSC)
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
DE-RADICALIZATION, COUNTER-TERRORISM MIGRATION IN NORTHERN NIGERIA (DCM)
DE-RADICALIZATION, COUNTER-TERRORISM MIGRATION IN NORTHERN NIGERIA (DCM)
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- No. of officers trained - No of trained personnel who have disseminated the training to their officers and men. - No. of judiciary staff benefitting from capacity building. - No. of courts re-opened as a result of transferred skills. - No. of females trained. - No. of young men and women, community elders and religious leaders who have benefitted from de-radicalization programmes - No. of security incidents reported to the law enforcement agencies in the targeted communities - No. of communities/villages benefitting from local dialogues on radicalization and irregular migration - At least 50% of targeted communities are in the border region.

comment.narrative: Inadequate knowledge of terrorism-related investigation techniques has rendered ineffective, the approaches adopted by security agencies. Inadequate knowledge of prosecutorial and adjudication techniques related to terrorism by state judicial service commissions. Increased presence of extremist messages in local communities. Increased cases of young persons’ joining terrorist groups. Exacerbated communal/community conflicts Low capacity to engage in ‘whole of community’ preventive initiatives Lack of synergy between communities and security agencies in preventing extremism and irregular migration;

90% of the targeted officers have been trained 50% of the trained personnel have transferred knowledge to operational and tactical-level officers in the North East. 30% of the trainees are women INDICATIVE ACTIVITIES - 200 clerics, young persons, women and community leaders trained on counter-narratives. - 80% of trained persons transfers the skills to their communities. - 50% of beneficiaries are in the border region. - 10 Communities are supported (primarily in Borno and Adamawa States). - 50% of beneficiary communities establish platforms for regular interface with security agencies on migration issues and de-radicalization. - Decreasing trend in the number of tensions between security agents and communities in benefiting communities - Dissemination of knowledge product in 19 Northern states by March 2017.
- 116 officials trained. 42 of them are female. - 169 judicial officers trained. - 200 religious clerics trained.

SUPPORT TO EARLY RECOVERY IN THE NORTH EAST OF NIGERIA

description.narrative: The project responds to the need to immediately stabilize communities across Borno, Yobe and Adamawa States of Nigeria which were devastated by the Boko Haram insurgency through the provision of support in 4 inter-related areas.

title.narrative: Empwr Livli Sup Victim BH NE

description.narrative: Empowerment and Livelihoods Support for the Victims of Boko Haram Insurgency in the North East
The main objective of this project is to increase the pool of skilled manpower in order to alleviate the acute shortages of employable labour in Lagos state.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
The objective of this project is to increase the pool of skilled manpower in order to alleviate the acute shortages of employable labour in Lagos state.
policy, planning and administration

title.narrative: Strengthening economic planning and SDGs implementation

description.narrative: Project will enhance institutional human resource capacity of budget national planning ministry, natnl. bureau of statistics SDG office to design, implement monitor medium long term plans in line with country-level sectoral priorities SDGs .
